communities.title: Our Communities
communities.subtitle: Communities that pray, serve and share our faith together at St. Anthony of Padua Basilica
communities.strongerDescription: Our church hosts various community groups. Each community, with their different charisms and areas of service, acts together with the same faith and love. Join us!
communities.howToJoinText1: There are no prerequisites to join our communities. You can come to the church on the meeting days of the community you are interested in, get acquainted, ask your questions and join the group.
communities.howToJoinText2: Each community has its own meeting days and times. For detailed information, you can visit the relevant community page or contact our church office.
communities.meetingsText1: Our communities regularly organize weekly prayer meetings, monthly formations, annual retreats and special events. Through these activities, we strengthen our spirituality, get to know each other and strengthen our community bonds.
communities.meetingsText2: You can check our church bulletin to follow our event calendar and stay informed about current announcements.
communities.joinUsDescription: Contact us to learn more about our communities and discover which community is right for you.

art.title: Art & Architecture
art.subtitle: The pearl of Istanbul with its Neo-Gothic architecture and magnificent artworks
art.architecturalStyleDesc: St. Anthony of Padua Basilica is one of the most impressive Neo-Gothic structures of the early 20th century. Designed by Italian architect Giulio Mongeri, the church masterfully integrates the characteristic features of European Gothic architecture into the fabric of Ottoman Istanbul.
art.facadeDesc1: The church's facade facing Istiklal Street attracts attention with its pointed arches, rose windows, and detailed stonework. The statue of the Virgin Mary above the main portal welcomes visitors.
art.facadeDesc2: The bells located in the two side towers have been one of the sounds of Istiklal Street for a century.
art.interiorArtDesc: The church's interior brings together the works of Italian and local artists. The statue of St. Anthony at the altar was specially brought from Padua in 1912.
art.sculpturesDesc: Each of the twelve apostle sculptures was crafted by a different artist, reflecting the synthesis of Neo-Classical and Neo-Gothic styles.
art.mosaicsDesc: The mosaics in the apse dome and side chapels depict scenes from the life of Jesus:
art.baptismSceneDesc: Jesus' baptism in the Jordan River, rendered in gold and blue tones
art.lastSupperDesc: Inspired by Leonardo da Vinci's famous work
art.paintingsFrescoesDesc: On the side nave walls, there are scenes from the life of St. Francis and portraits of Catholic saints. These works were created by Italian artists in the 1920s.
art.lightSpaceDesc: Natural light entering through the high windows creates a changing atmosphere in the interior throughout the day. This play of light, a characteristic feature of Gothic architecture, offers a spiritual experience.
art.latinCrossDesc: The church has a classic Latin cross plan: a long nave, transept, and semicircular apse
art.concreteDesc: Reinforced concrete, one of the most advanced construction techniques of the period, was used
art.redBrickDesc: The red brick used on the facade and interior was specially imported from Marseille
art.tuscanStyleDesc: The column capitals and arches reflect the architectural tradition of the Italian Tuscany region
art.culturalSignificanceDesc1: St. Anthony of Padua Basilica is not just a place of worship, but also an important symbol of Istanbul's multicultural heritage. For centuries, it has hosted the city's Catholic community and also served as a meeting point for people of different faiths.
art.culturalSignificanceDesc2: In addition to its architectural value, the church is a symbol of the cultural dialogue with Europe during Istanbul's modernization process. Celebrating its 100th anniversary in 2012, the church today hosts both religious and cultural events.

franciscans.title: The Franciscans
franciscans.subtitle: 800 years of service following St. Francis
franciscans.intro: The Franciscan Order, which administers St. Anthony of Padua Basilica, is a Catholic religious order founded by St. Francis in 1209, with approximately 12,000 friars worldwide today.
franciscans.whoAreDesc1: The Franciscans are a Catholic religious community based on the teachings of St. Francis of Assisi, Italy (1181-1226). Coming from a wealthy merchant family, St. Francis renounced material possessions at a young age and devoted his life to living among the poor and preaching the Gospel in a simple way.
franciscans.whoAreDesc2: Francis's charism was to see God's presence in creation, love the poor, work for peace, and view all creation with fraternal eyes. This spiritual perspective forms the foundation of the Franciscan Order.
franciscans.pillar1Desc: St. Francis called poverty 'Our Lady.' Franciscans follow Jesus's path by avoiding material possessions and living a simple life.
franciscans.pillar2Desc: The greeting of peace is the distinctive mark of Franciscans. They spread love, tolerance, and reconciliation everywhere.
franciscans.pillar3Desc: In the 'Canticle of the Sun,' St. Francis addresses all creation as brothers and sisters. Environmental awareness and respect for nature are at the heart of the Franciscan spirit.
franciscans.pillar4Desc: Franciscans are dedicated to spreading the Gospel by living it and preaching it in words.
franciscans.istanbulDesc1: The Franciscans have been serving continuously in Istanbul since 1230. They first settled in Galata, then in Beyoğlu in 1724.
franciscans.istanbulDesc2: Today, the Franciscan friars serving at St. Anthony of Padua Basilica not only provide liturgical services but also offer social assistance, education, and spiritual guidance.
franciscans.service5: Assistance to the poor and social service
franciscans.communityDesc: The Franciscan community at St. Anthony of Padua Basilica is not composed only of friars. Secular Franciscans (SFO - Secular Franciscan Order) and various community groups sharing the Franciscan spirit are also part of the larger family.
franciscans.stFrancisDesc: Giovanni di Pietro Bernardone of Assisi radically changed his life after a profound spiritual experience during war captivity. Rejecting his family's wealth, he lived the Gospel among the poor. In 1209, he founded his order with the approval of Pope Innocent III. He received the stigmata in 1224 and died in Assisi in 1226. He was canonized by Pope Gregory IX in 1228.
